question: My father is over 80 years old, in relatively good shape, has had mild diabetes type II diagnosed when he was about 20 years old, and good cholesterol levels.  He is able to control his diabetes primarily through his diet.  His physician just prescribed him pravastatin, presumably to prevent heart complications due to his diabetes.  Is this routinely done?  Aren't there other drugs, such as aspirin (which my father already takes daily), that can prevent heart disease but with less side-effects than statins?
title: Pravastatin for diabetes II
